review.title: A Multilingual FrameNet-based Grammar and Lexicon for Controlled Natural Language
review.abstract: Berkeley FrameNet is a lexico-semantic resource for English based on the theory of frame semantics. It has been exploited in a range of natural language processing applications and has inspired the development of framenets for many languages. We present a methodological approach to the extraction and generation of a computational multilingual FrameNet-based grammar and lexicon. The approach leverages FrameNet-annotated corpora to automatically extract a set of cross-lingual semantico-syntactic valence patterns. Based on data from Berkeley FrameNet and Swedish FrameNet, the proposed approach has been implemented in Grammatical Framework (GF), a categorial grammar formalism specialized for multilingual grammars. The implementation of the grammar and lexicon is supported by the design of FrameNet, providing a frame semantic abstraction layer, an interlingual semantic API (application programming interface), over the interlingual syntactic API already provided by GF Resource Grammar Library. The evaluation of the acquired grammar and lexicon shows the feasibility of the approach. Additionally, we illustrate how the FrameNet-based grammar and lexicon are exploited in two distinct multilingual controlled natural language applications. The produced resources are available under an open source license.

sections.heading: 6 Evaluation
sections.text: We have performed a simple intrinsic and extrinsic evaluation of the acquired FN-based grammar and lexicon. For an initial intrinsic evaluation, we count the number of examples in the source corpora that belong to the set of split frames and that are covered by the common semantic and syntactic valence patterns. Corpus examples are judged by the sentence patterns they represent, without taking into account the non-core FEs, the concrete prepositions and the word order, but including the syntactic roles and the grammatical voice. This means that the original sentences are generally covered by paraphrases. We have 57,615 examples from BFN and 3,348 examples from SweFN that belong to the common set of 483 frames. For both BFN and SweFN, the precise sentences are covered by 869 patterns.

sections.heading: 8 Related Work
sections.text: The main difference between this work and previous approaches to CNL grammar is that we strive to use a robust and well-established semantic model in grammar development. Our approach can be compared to the work on multilingual verbalization of modular ontologies using GF and lemon (Davis et al, 2012), the Lexicon Model for Ontologies. We use additional lexical information about syntactical arguments for building the concrete syntax. Grounding NLG using the frame semantics theory has been addressed in the work on generating text in scene (Coyne et al, 2011) and in the work on text generation for navigation tasks (Roth and Frank, 2010). In this research, the content of frames is supported by aligning between the frame semantics structure and the domain semantics representation. Discourse is supported by the use of aggregation and pronominalization techniques for navigation tasks (Roth and Frank, 2010). sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: In this article, we presented a computational approach to multilingual grammar and lexicon extraction and generation from FN-annotated corpora. Methodology for constructing grammars and lexicographies was evaluated in a series of experiments. Results show that we are able to generalize across a number of valence patterns to capture the semantics and syntax of two languages with a common FN-based abstract syntax. We discussed a number of potential improvements to achieve better results that would lead to greater coverage, but the current coverage is already of practical use. We tested the feasibility of the generated grammar library as a semantic API for developing CNL applications in GF.

referenceMentions.context: The future potential of our approach is to provide a means for multilingual verbalization of FN-annotated knowledge bases that have been populated by FN-based information extraction systems (Das et al, 2014) and that could be automatically mapped to the appropriate frame constructors, similarly as sketched by Barzdins (2014).
Berkeley FrameNet (Fillmore et al, 2003) is a lexico-semantic resource based on the theory of frame semantics (Fillmore, 1985).

The FrameNet approach to frame semantics, approbated in BFN, provides a benchmark for representing large amounts of word senses and word usage patterns through the linguistic annotation of corpus examples, therefore the exploitation of FN-like resources has been appealing for a range of advanced NLP applications such as semantic parsing (Das et al, 2014), information extraction (Moschitti et al, 2003) and natural language generation (Roth and Frank, 2009).
There are FNs available for German, Japanese, Spanish (Boas, 2009) and Swedish (Borin et al, 2010).

The grounding of NLG using the frame semantics theory has been addressed in the work on text-to-scene generation (Coyne et al, 2011) and in the work on text generation for navigational tasks (Roth and Frank, 2010).

In the cultural heritage use case, we also show how an application which utilizes the FN-based grammar can become more discourse-oriented; something that is necessary in actual NLG applications and that has been demonstrated in GF before (Dannélls, 2010).
As suggested before (Gruzitis and Barzdins, 2010), a FN-like approach can be used to deal with polysemy in CNL texts.
